results.title: Life in the Nile Valley
results.brief_description: Traces the course of the Nile River from Aswan north to Cairo. Within the narrow valley of the river, 15,000,000 people live - essentially an agricultural society which has been dependant on the Nile for many hundreds of years. A study is made of the daily activities of a typical Egyptian farm family; the ploughing and irrigation of the land, unaltered since ancient times; the home life of the women and school activities.

results.title: Life in the lowlands: the Netherlands
results.brief_description: Shows life in the polda lands of Holland with emphasis on the theme of man’s eternal struggle against nature. Demonstrates how dams and dikes are constructed and shows typical characteristics of the land; windmills, modes of transport, industries and life on the dairy farm.

results.title: Life in the Kimberleys
results.creator_credit: Rhys Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Rhys Bedford has a lot of doors open to him, now that he is the recipient of a scholarship at Hale College in Western Australia. But it is when he returns to his family in Kununurra that Bedford gets to explore and reconnect with his country and heritage.

results.title: Life in the Highlands
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and John C. Elder
results.brief_description: A study of the effect of geographical and other environmental factors on the life of the crofters of the Scottish highlands. The crofter’s house, and the sources of supply of water and fuel are seen, together with the cultivation of crops on their patch of ground in the summer, and their winter occupation of spinning and weaving the wool obtained from their sheep.

results.title: Life in the high Andes
results.brief_description: Explains how life in high mountain regions in affected by altitude and climate. Pictures an Indian family living in a mountain valley of Peru, and shows how farming, grazing, and weaving are important to their lives. Discusses the influences of the ancient Incan civilization on these people and presents a view on market day in the village.

results.title: Life in the freezer
results.brief_description: David Attenborough reveals the stunning beauty of Antarctica. At one and a half times the size of the United States, it has a population of only 800 people. Three quarters of the world’s fresh water envelops it in a layer of ice so thick it conceals mountain ranges as vast as the Alps. With temperatures below 70 degrees C. and winds of 120mph, Antarctica is the coldest, loneliest place on Earth. However, it is also a place of majestic beauty which can support astonishingly rich and varied forms of wildlife. Incomparable standards of natural history filming trace Antarctica’s seasonal cycle from the long winter months when the formation of ice almost doubles its surface area, to the brief summer when the race to breed accelerates. With scenes of sheer beauty, passion, comedy, aggression and sadness, this documentary is an unmissable opportunity to experience the last true wilderness on Earth.

results.brief_description: The viewer is taken into the Australian desert and shown the amazing variety of plants and animals and informed how they manage to survive in such extreme conditions.

results.title: Life in the balance
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the principals and practices of cardiopulmonary resuscitation within the coronary care unit. Shows how a coronary care unit can provide for the prevention, detection and treatment of serious arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrest.

results.title: Life in northern lands: Norway
results.brief_description: A Norwegian farm family, living near Bergen, illustrate how people in a northerly latitude adjust their lives and seasonal occupations to the demands of climate and topography. The family is seen harvesting hay and grains during the short Norwegian summer. In the winter-time children sky to school and their brothers and fathers are busy fishing and cutting timber.

results.title: Life in North China
results.brief_description: The mountains of Manchuria are dotted with rural communes - farm villages operating as production teams, working the land on a collective basis. While many of the farming techniques are primitive, the people are building towards an efficient tomorrow by operating small basic industries. Some are constructing their own chemical fertiliser plants and agricultural colleges. Their spirit of self-sufficiency and co-operation has its parallel in the urban industrial centres, where factory workers often build their own essential manufacturing equipment, and all major decisions in the plant are made by a committee of workers, technicians, and management officers. At harvest time, thousands of teachers, students and workers leave the cities to work beside their countrymen in the fields. Later, on National Liberation Day, these two life-styles merge again in celebration of their growing nation.
